Explicit subclasses of Command

0 voters

Hey everyone!  I’m running this poll for the third year in a row now ( 2024 , 2023 ), to track the adoption/consumption of the (now no-longer that new) “v2” Commands API.

Recall that commands can be created two ways:

you can write a subclass of Command with overrides for each lifecycle method ( initialize , execute , isFinished , end ) containing your command logic, and then construct an instance of that subclass

you can pass your code as a callback (e.g. by method reference or lambda function) to a factory function or Command subclass constructor

As explained in the earlier threads, WPILib has been moving towards a more-functional/less OO-driven architecture for several years now - but as past polls have shown, legacy subclass interactions are still quite popular.

Please share how you primarily interacted with the Command-based framework this year.  Feel free to respond with further details below.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Josh P
posts.cooked:
We started mostly inline (see the registerXXXX methods in RobotContainer here ), but when my  students needed to make Named Commands for use with pathplanner they for one reason or another made explicit command classes for each (I was busy doing volunteer stuff during the time they developed this).

This year our subsystems were all either finite state machines or moving one control loop to a setpoint, so commands were simple calls to change the state of the subsystem and most control code was handled in our subsystem periodic methods.

I will try to remember to pick their brains on why they went that way and bring the feedback back to the thread.

(In the past I/we always did explicit classes but this year tried to stay inline for commands.)

posts.name: Christopher149
posts.cooked: Our were mostly inline, with a couple explicit classes for something more complicated (like auto-align to a reef pole).

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC857 lead mentor / FTC10723+13284+15270 lead mentor

posts.name: Noah Zemlin
posts.cooked: This year ours was a split of both too, usually just depending on whichever programmer was the one writing the code. We did 100% explicit subclasses last year. I intend to guide the programmers to near 100% inline/factory functions for next year with the exception of highly complex commands with lots of logic (combined auto align + scoring was one for this year). Trimming down the 1000 different XYZCommand.java files made a huge difference for code readability and traceability.

posts.name: Sam Maier
posts.cooked: We use inline for most of our really basic commands, but we tend to put a lot of logic into our commands and it gets unweildy, so our default is still subclasses. We also like the convenience of referencing commands in command groups, and I’m not sure how we’d compose command groups of anonymous inner classes.

posts.name: Paul Regnier
posts.cooked: we started using command factories this year (thanks @bovlb !) for nearly all our commands (barring a few long sequences that had their own files). It saved so much time compared to writing out a whole file, and binding commands to buttons was a lot simpler and cleaner as well. Our robot this year did not need to be controlled in a state machine style (incredibly simple to run off of a few preset sequences), and from what I’ve seen that is one of the areas where command factories excel, so I’m excited to use this new convention even more going forward!

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
microbuns:

I’m not sure how we’d compose command groups of anonymous inner classes.

Factory methods!

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
our students found that having lots of little files made it easier to keep track of all the many layers of different parallel/sequential/parallel/sequential stuff they did this year, and also keep track of various parallel experiments they were working on.

another minor issue for us was wanting to be able to log the active command, so it needs a name, and the collections need to log appropriately as well.  as i understand it, neither the inline factories nor the WPILib collections do that?

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: We did purely factory-methods this year. It worked very well for the most part, but there is a layer of organization which has to be reinvented, as opposed to the subclass approach. For example, all our multi-subsystem factories were dumped into the Autos class along with other utility functions for determining selected scoring operation. Some factories needed class-scope objects like Trapezoid Profiles or SwerveRequests, so those were defined adjacent to the factory method. With good comments this can stay organized, but we did end up with the Drivebase class having a lot of fairly complex drivebase-only command logic within it, and the Autos class got hard to scroll through.

posts.name: Aidan
posts.cooked:
This is my first year running programming for our team. Looking at our 2024 code, we used more command classes. For some reason, this looked more difficult than creating inline commands to me. (Looking now, I actually think command classes are more readable.)

We mostly used inline commands up until the week before competition (we had programmed subsystems as they were being built, and therefore we couldn’t test much of our code, other than a drive base), when I realized that a lack of command-based knowledge meant that half of our inline commands just didn’t react to anything. After this, we tried command classes, they work, all good now. There are some things I’m still figuring out, but I find them a lot simpler.

Commands.runOnce() is used quite a lot though.

My answer basically changed throughout the season, but I’m going to answer inline, just due to how many we have leftover in the code.

posts.name: Sam Maier
posts.cooked: Yep, that makes sense. The thing I’ve struggled with is maybe higher level than that - where the factory methods belong. Should these be on the Subsystems, or as static methods on RobotContainer or some other global class? Having them in Subsystems seems really nice until you need to actuate on >1 subsystem at a time. But creating a mega class that holds all commands seems like it’d get unwieldy. What’s the “WPILib recommended” way of doing this? Are my commands doing too much if they require >1 Subsystem, and I should instead be composing commands from the different Subsystems together? Or is it totally expected to use 2/3 Subsystems in many commands and you should just have a mega file which lists and details every command?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Subsystems should expose their contracts as command factories in subsystem scope.  Composite commands using multiple subsystems can be defined in RobotContainer, or else in some command factory helper class into which you inject the subsystems.

posts.name: JJ Sessa
posts.cooked:
Oblarg:

As explained in the earlier threads, WPILib has been moving towards a more-functional/less OO-driven architecture for several years now - but as past polls have shown, legacy subclass interactions are still quite popular.

Is there a good example of this? We’ve been pretty unhappy with the heavy OO architecture and have slowly been getting more functional with lots of suppliers and light state machines controlled by commands. Buts its hard to break old habits and I haven’t seen a good example of this, only talk that “triggers are the new way you should be doing most things”

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: The RapidReactCommandBot example is the most architecturally up-to-date of the official examples at the moment.  I know some people are working on docs improvements this summer, so this may change.

posts.name: Oliver
posts.cooked:
we only had commands returned from subsystem files, but everything was run from an overarching “superstructure” class (finite state machine), which extensively utilized Triggers to explicitly define the transitions among states. (file for reference) Stealth2025/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/Superstructure.java at main · Stealth-Robotics/Stealth2025 · GitHub

shoutout to 8033 for this specific state machine approach. I would highly recommend it

Our programmers and I love inline commands, our robot in 24’ and this year didn’t need a state machine, so everything could be programmed as sequences. They also used them in our NamedCommands for auto routines.

Our programmers typically create basic commands as subclasses, like RunIntake or ShootCoral etc. and then use the Command Factories API to chain them together like a sequence.

Ex:

However, it made our RobotContainer class quite large and clunky to read, and it got really weird when our lead programmer tried to code an auto-align to the reef, so we put the complex stuff in its own Command class instead.

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked:
jjsessa:

I haven’t seen a good example of this, only talk that “triggers are the new way you should be doing most things”

We switched to a mostly trigger-based architecture this year. We just made a single file with a whole bunch of Triggers that represented any action the robot took or any sort of measurement we wanted to react to.

Pretty much all our commands are just inline inside the subsystem and are bound to these triggers in a bindCommands() method that gets called on init.

This was all heavily inspired by SpectrumLib, Allen has a video on it here: https://youtu.be/JMCk4XkBNCU?si=GiV7vqfT80B2YSb8

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
truher:

another minor issue for us was wanting to be able to log the active command, so it needs a name

I recommend use of the withName decorator. You should be using this liberally inside your command factories and anywhere you are compounding commands.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
truher:

as i understand it, neither the inline factories nor the WPILib collections do that?

Commands.idle().withName("Busywork") will do it. You just need this to be at the end of the composition (I think).

This was the first year we really doubled down on a Trigger+Command factory interface. I found it worked quite well, and was way cleaner than prior years using void doSomething() interfaces. On trivial commands, it was just less syntax, and on more complex ones (like trapezoidal profiles) it gave a single place to properly manage internal states.

I think the biggest pain point we had in this transition was making it clear when commands end. Learned the hard way that most factories should not end  by default. Then, either compose a condition, or have a secondary factory that does this as a shorthand.

The only unresolved pain point we ran into was that we didn’t have a robust superstructure state machine flow. This turned out to be needed, but haven’t exactly found something that vibes with our command flow patterns. It’s now the summer project.

posts.name: Oliver
posts.cooked: have you checked out the 8033 approach? I really liked it and found it really easy to implement. you can check out their code or ours for examples for this year.
